Line 9: Line 9:
==History==
==History==
[[Herodotus]] writes in [[Histories (Herodotus)|''The Histories'']] that, to discourage intercourse with a corpse, ancient [[Egypt]]ians left deceased beautiful women to decay for "three or four days" before giving them to the [[embalmers]].<ref>Herodotus ([[circa|c.]] 440 BC). ''The Histories'', [http://www.gutenberg.org/dirs/etext01/1hofh10.txt Book II], 89:
[[Herodotus]] writes in [[Histories (Herodotus)|''The Histories'']] that, to discourage intercourse with a corpse, ancient [[Egypt]]ians left deceased beautiful women to decay for "three or four days" before giving them to the [[embalmers]].<ref>Herodotus ([[circa|c.]] 440 BC). ''The Histories'', [http://www.gutenberg.org/dirs/etext01/1hofh10.txt Book II], 89:
â
:"The wives of men of rank when they die are not given at once to be embalmed, nor such women as are very beautiful or of greater regard than others, but on the third or fourth day after their death (and not before) they are delivered to the embalmers. They do so about this matter in order that the embalmers may not abuse their women, for they say that one of them was taken once doing so to the corpse of a woman lately dead, and his fellow-craftsman gave information."</ref><ref>Brill, Abraham A. (1941). "Necrophilia," ''Journal of Criminal Psychopathology'', 2(4), 433-443.</ref><ref name="klaf"/>
+
:"The wives of men of rank when they die are not given at once to be embalmed, nor such women as are very beautiful or of greater regard than others, but on the third or fourth day after their death (and not before) they are delivered to the embalmers. They do so about this matter in order that the embalmers may not abuse their women, for they say that one of them was taken once doing so to the corpse of a woman lately dead, and his fellow-craftsman gave information."</ref><ref>Brill, Abraham A. (1941). "Necrophilia," ''Journal of Criminal Psychopathology'', 2(4), 433-443.</ref><ref name="klaf"/>
In some societies the practice was enacted owing to a belief that the soul of an unmarried woman would not find peace; among the [[Jingpo|Kachin]] of [[Myanmar]], versions of a marriage ceremony were held to lay a dead virgin to rest, which would involve intercourse with the corpse. Similar practices existed in some pre-modern [[Central Europe]]an societies when a woman who was engaged to be married died before the wedding.<ref>Walker, Benjamin. ''Encyclopaedia of Metaphysical Medicine'', Routledge 1978, pp. 191-2. Walker cites Rollo Ahmed, ''The Black Art'', John Long, London, 1936, in support.</ref>
In some societies the practice was enacted owing to a belief that the soul of an unmarried woman would not find peace; among the [[Jingpo|Kachin]] of [[Myanmar]], versions of a marriage ceremony were held to lay a dead virgin to rest, which would involve intercourse with the corpse. Similar practices existed in some pre-modern [[Central Europe]]an societies when a woman who was engaged to be married died before the wedding.<ref>Walker, Benjamin. ''Encyclopaedia of Metaphysical Medicine'', Routledge 1978, pp. 191-2. Walker cites Rollo Ahmed, ''The Black Art'', John Long, London, 1936, in support.</ref>
Line 32: Line 32:
In 1958, Klaf and Brown<ref name="klaf">Klaf, Franklin S., and Brown, William (1958). "Necrophilia: Brief Review and Case Report," ''the Psychoanalytic Quarterly'', 29(143), 645-652. "Inhibited forms of necrophilia and necrophilic fantasies may occur more commonly then is generally realized."</ref> commented that, although rarely described, necrophilic [[fantasy (psychology)|fantasies]] may occur more often than is generally supposed.
In 1958, Klaf and Brown<ref name="klaf">Klaf, Franklin S., and Brown, William (1958). "Necrophilia: Brief Review and Case Report," ''the Psychoanalytic Quarterly'', 29(143), 645-652. "Inhibited forms of necrophilia and necrophilic fantasies may occur more commonly then is generally realized."</ref> commented that, although rarely described, necrophilic [[fantasy (psychology)|fantasies]] may occur more often than is generally supposed.
â
Rosman and Resnick<ref name="rosman">Rosman, Jonathan P., and Resnick, Phillip J. (1989). [http://www.burknet.com/robsfantasy/section11a.html "Sexual attraction to corpses: a psychiatric review of necrophilia,"] ''Bulletin of the American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law'', 17, 153-163.</ref> (1989) theorized that either of the following situations could be antecedents to necrophilia (pp. 161):
+
Rosman and Resnick<ref name="rosman">Rosman, Jonathan P., and Resnick, Phillip J. (1989). [http://www.burknet.com/robsfantasy/section11a.html "Sexual attraction to corpses: a psychiatric review of necrophilia,"] ''Bulletin of the American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law'', 17, 153-163.</ref> (1989) theorized that either of the following situations could be antecedents to necrophilia (pp. 161):
â
#The necrophile develops poor [[self-esteem]], perhaps due in part to a significant loss;
+
#The necrophile develops poor [[self-esteem]], perhaps due in part to a significant loss;
â
#:(a) He/she is very fearful of rejection by women/men and he/she desires a sexual partner who is incapable of rejecting him/her; and/or
+
#:(a) He/she is very fearful of rejection by women/men and he/she desires a sexual partner who is incapable of rejecting him/her; and/or
#:(b) He/she is fearful of the dead, and transforms his/her fear — by means of [[reaction formation]] — into a desire.
#:(b) He/she is fearful of the dead, and transforms his/her fear — by means of [[reaction formation]] — into a desire.
#He/she develops an exciting fantasy of sex with a corpse, sometimes after exposure to a corpse.</blockquote>
#He/she develops an exciting fantasy of sex with a corpse, sometimes after exposure to a corpse.</blockquote>
The authors also reported that, of their sample of 'necrophiliacs,':
The authors also reported that, of their sample of 'necrophiliacs,':
*68% were motivated by a desire for an unresisting and unrejecting partner;
*68% were motivated by a desire for an unresisting and unrejecting partner;
â
*21% by a want for reunion with a lost partner;
+
*21% by a want for reunion with a lost partner;
*15% by sexual attraction to dead people;
*15% by sexual attraction to dead people;
*15% by a desire for comfort or to overcome feelings of isolation; and
*15% by a desire for comfort or to overcome feelings of isolation; and
â
*11% by a desire to remedy low self-esteem by expressing power over a corpse (pp. 159).
+
*11% by a desire to remedy low self-esteem by expressing power over a corpse (pp. 159).
At the end of their own report, Rosman and Resnick wrote that their study should only be used like a spring-board for further, more in depth, research.
At the end of their own report, Rosman and Resnick wrote that their study should only be used like a spring-board for further, more in depth, research.
â
Minor modern researches conducted in [[England]] have shown that some necrophiles tend to choose a dead mate after failing to create romantic attachments with the living {{Fact|date=June 2007}}.
+
Minor modern researches conducted in [[England]] have shown that some necrophiles tend to choose a dead mate after failing to create romantic attachments with the living {{Citation needed|date=June 2007}}.
===Animals===
===Animals===
{{main|Davian behavior}}
{{main|Davian behavior}}
â
Necrophilia is known to occur in animals, with a number of confirmed observations.<ref name="Guardian 2: Electric Boogaloo">{{cite news | url = http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/research/improbable/story/0,,1437560,00.html | title = Randy rock doves join party with the dead | accessdate = 2007-06-17 | work = [[The Guardian]] | year = 2005 | location=London | date=2005-03-14}}</ref> [[Kees Moeliker]] allegedly made one of these observations while he was sitting in his office at the [[Natuurmuseum Rotterdam]], when he heard the distinctive thud of a bird hitting the glass facade of the building. Upon inspection, he discovered a drake (male) [[mallard]] lying dead about two meters from the building. Next to the downed bird there was a second drake mallard standing close by. As Moeliker observed the couple, the living drake picked at the corpse of the dead one for a few minutes and then mounted the corpse and began having sex with it. The act of necrophilia lasted for about 75 minutes, in which time, according to Moeliker, the living drake took two short breaks before resuming with copulating behavior. Moeliker surmised that at the time of the collision with the window the two mallards were engaged in a common pattern in [[duck]] behavior which is called "[[rape]] flight". "When one died the other one just went for it and didn't get any negative feedback — well, didn't get any feedback," according to Moeliker.<ref name="Mallard Duck">{{cite journal | author=C.W. Moeliker| title=The first case of homosexual necrophilia in the Anas platyrhynchos (Aves:Anatidae)| journal=Deinsea - Annual of the Natural History Museum Rotterdam| year=2001| volume=8| pages=243â247}}</ref><ref name="MallardDuck">{{cite news | url=http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/research/story/0,9865,1432991,00.html | title = Necrophilia among ducks ruffles research feathers|accessdate = 2007-06-17|publisher=Guardian Unlimited|year=2005|author=Donald MacLeod | location=London | date=2005-03-08}}</ref> This is the first recorded case of necrophilia in the [[mallard duck]]- though not the only recorded case of [[homosexuality]] within the bird family.<ref name="NYTSqueak">{{cite news |first=Dinitia |last=Smith | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/07/arts/07GAY.html?scp=1&sq=Love%20that%20dare%20not%20squeak%20its%20name&st=cse |title=Love That Dare Not Squeak Its Name |publisher=New York Times |page=7 |date=2004-02-07}}</ref>
+
Necrophilia is known to occur in animals, with a number of confirmed observations.<ref name="Guardian 2: Electric Boogaloo">{{cite news | url = http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/research/improbable/story/0,,1437560,00.html | title = Randy rock doves join party with the dead | accessdate = 2007-06-17 | work = [[The Guardian]] | location=London | date=2005-03-14}}</ref> [[Kees Moeliker]] allegedly made one of these observations while he was sitting in his office at the [[Natuurmuseum Rotterdam]], when he heard the distinctive thud of a bird hitting the glass facade of the building. Upon inspection, he discovered a drake (male) [[mallard]] lying dead about two meters from the building. Next to the downed bird there was a second drake mallard standing close by. As Moeliker observed the couple, the living drake picked at the corpse of the dead one for a few minutes and then mounted the corpse and began having sex with it. The act of necrophilia lasted for about 75 minutes, in which time, according to Moeliker, the living drake took two short breaks before resuming with copulating behavior. Moeliker surmised that at the time of the collision with the window the two mallards were engaged in a common pattern in [[duck]] behavior which is called "[[rape]] flight". "When one died the other one just went for it and didn't get any negative feedback — well, didn't get any feedback," according to Moeliker.<ref name="Mallard Duck">{{cite journal | author=C.W. Moeliker| title=The first case of homosexual necrophilia in the Anas platyrhynchos (Aves:Anatidae)| journal=Deinsea - Annual of the Natural History Museum Rotterdam| year=2001| volume=8| pages=243â247}}</ref><ref name="MallardDuck">{{cite news | url=http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/research/story/0,9865,1432991,00.html | title = Necrophilia among ducks ruffles research feathers|accessdate = 2007-06-17|publisher=Guardian Unlimited|author=Donald MacLeod | location=London | date=2005-03-08}}</ref> This is the first recorded case of necrophilia in the [[mallard duck]]- though not the only recorded case of [[homosexuality]] within the bird family.<ref name="NYTSqueak">{{cite news |first=Dinitia |last=Smith | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/07/arts/07GAY.html?scp=1&sq=Love%20that%20dare%20not%20squeak%20its%20name&st=cse |title=Love That Dare Not Squeak Its Name |publisher=New York Times |page=7 |date=2004-02-07}}</ref>
The film ''The Cane Toads: an Unnatural History'' shows a male toad copulating with a female toad who has been run over by a car. He goes on to do this for eight hours.<ref>Lewis, 1989 S. Lewis, Cane Toads: an Unnatural History, Doubleday, New York (1989).</ref>
The film ''The Cane Toads: an Unnatural History'' shows a male toad copulating with a female toad who has been run over by a car. He goes on to do this for eight hours.<ref>Lewis, 1989 S. Lewis, Cane Toads: an Unnatural History, Doubleday, New York (1989).</ref>
Line 58: Line 58:
==Legality==
==Legality==
â  
===New Zealand===
===New Zealand===
Under Section 150 of the New Zealand Crimes Act 1961, it is an offence for there to be "misconduct in respect to human remains." This statute may be applicable to necrophilia, although it should be noted that there is no case law as yet that would test this observation <ref>Butterworths Crimes Act 1961: Wellington: Butterworths: 2003</ref>
Under Section 150 of the New Zealand Crimes Act 1961, it is an offence for there to be "misconduct in respect to human remains." This statute may be applicable to necrophilia, although it should be noted that there is no case law as yet that would test this observation <ref>Butterworths Crimes Act 1961: Wellington: Butterworths: 2003</ref>
Line 68: Line 67:
shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.</blockquote>
shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.</blockquote>
Although Necrophilia is not explicitly stated in IPC, a necrophiliac may be convicted under the above section in the Indian Penal Code.
Although Necrophilia is not explicitly stated in IPC, a necrophiliac may be convicted under the above section in the Indian Penal Code.
â
There have been several allegations by relatives of dead women, that the dead bodies of their kin were defiled in the night by mortuary attendants, but none have been proven. <ref name="aggrawal">{{cite book | first=Anil | last=Aggrawal | coauthors= | title=Forensic and Medico-legal Aspects of Sexual Crimes and Unusual Sexual Practices | publisher=[[CRC Press]] | location=Boca Raton | year=2009 | isbn=1420043080 | curly=true |url=http://crcpress.com/product/isbn/9781420043082}}</ref>
+
There have been several allegations by relatives of dead women, that the dead bodies of their kin were defiled in the night by mortuary attendants, but none have been proven.<ref name="aggrawal">{{cite book | first=Anil | last=Aggrawal | coauthors= | title=Forensic and Medico-legal Aspects of Sexual Crimes and Unusual Sexual Practices | publisher=[[CRC Press]] | location=Boca Raton | year=2009 | isbn=1420043080 | curly=true |url=http://crcpress.com/product/isbn/9781420043082}}</ref>
In some cases, where a woman was alleged to have been [[rape]]d and murdered and the [[autopsy]] surgeon failed to find any signs of rape, the relatives have approached the authorities for a second postmortem. The second postmortem is invariably conducted at a different hospital, often necessitating the deposit of the body overnight at the mortuary of the second hospital. In cases where the second autopsy surgeon finds signs of rape, the defendants have been known to allege that the dead body was defiled by drunk mortuary attendants at night. However, no such allegation has been proven in a court of law.<ref name="aggrawal">{{cite book | first=Anil | last=Aggrawal | coauthors= | title=Forensic and Medico-legal Aspects of Sexual Crimes and Unusual Sexual Practices | publisher=[[CRC Press]] | location=Boca Raton | year=2008 | isbn=1420043080 | curly=true}}</ref>
In some cases, where a woman was alleged to have been [[rape]]d and murdered and the [[autopsy]] surgeon failed to find any signs of rape, the relatives have approached the authorities for a second postmortem. The second postmortem is invariably conducted at a different hospital, often necessitating the deposit of the body overnight at the mortuary of the second hospital. In cases where the second autopsy surgeon finds signs of rape, the defendants have been known to allege that the dead body was defiled by drunk mortuary attendants at night. However, no such allegation has been proven in a court of law.<ref name="aggrawal">{{cite book | first=Anil | last=Aggrawal | coauthors= | title=Forensic and Medico-legal Aspects of Sexual Crimes and Unusual Sexual Practices | publisher=[[CRC Press]] | location=Boca Raton | year=2008 | isbn=1420043080 | curly=true}}</ref>
Line 78: Line 77:
===United States===
===United States===
â
As of May 2006, there is no federal legislation specifically barring sex with a corpse.{{cn}} Multiple states have their own laws:
+
As of May 2006, there is no federal legislation specifically barring sex with a corpse.{{Citation needed|date=October 2010}} Multiple states have their own laws:
*[[Alabama]] - Class C [[felony]] under [http://www.legislature.state.al.us/CodeofAlabama/1975/13A-11-13.htm 13A-11-13]
*[[Alabama]] - Class C [[felony]] under [http://www.legislature.state.al.us/CodeofAlabama/1975/13A-11-13.htm 13A-11-13]
Line 84: Line 83:

*[[Arkansas]] - Class D felony under [http://170.94.58.9/NXT/gateway.dll/ARCode/title03839.htm/subtitle04512.htm/chapter04513.htm/subchapter04514/section04515.htm 5-60-101]
*[[Arizona]] - Class 4 felony under [http://www.azleg.gov/FormatDocument.asp?inDoc=/ars/32/01364.htm&Title=32&DocType=ARS 32-1364]
*[[Arizona]] - Class 4 felony under [http://www.azleg.gov/FormatDocument.asp?inDoc=/ars/32/01364.htm&Title=32&DocType=ARS 32-1364]
â

*[[California]] - Felony under [http://www.leginfo.ca.gov/cgi-bin/displaycode?section=hsc&group=07001-08000&file=7050.5-7055 Health and Safety Code 7052], up to eight years in prison

*[[Colorado]] - Class 2 misdemeanor under [http://198.187.128.12/colorado/lpext.dll/Infobase4/29db9/2dc8a/2dca6?f=templates&fn=document-frame.htm&2.0#JD_18-13-101 18-13-101]
*[[Connecticut]] - Class A misdemeanor under [http://www.cga.ct.gov/2001/pub/Chap952.htm#sec53a-65.htm 53a-73a]
